;;

;;E;;每周;，新高。难怪市场上弥漫着不安的感觉。根据美国银行最新的月度调查，约 40% 的全球基金经理认为，人工智能 (;AI;) 股票——上涨的关键推动力——已经陷入泡沫。即使是华尔街最乐观的专家也认为，美国<小>;S;和<小>;P;500领先股指数在今年剩下的九个月里只能勉强维持小幅上涨。对于一些人来说，这种紧张预示着崩溃。但对于每个人来说，这都提出了一个问题：股价已经上涨了这么多，还有哪些股票具有良好的价值？

;

;“价值型股票非常不流行，这是有充分理由的。它们被定义为与其基础资产或收益相比价格较低的股票（与这些指标上价格较高但承诺利润迅速增长的“成长”股票相反）。如果这听起来很吸引人，那么近年来的回报却并非如此。过去十年，价值股一直落后于大盘，并被成长型股票远远甩在后面（见图 1）。 2022年，随着利率上升和投机资产价格遭受猛烈打击，钟摆似乎短暂地向后摆动。但只是简单地说：当前的牛​​市再次让价值股被其他股票击败。

;;
;;
;

;这种连续亏损导致许多人宣布价值投资已死。批评者表示，它很难计算出支撑当今许多最成功公司的无形资产和研究支出。投资工具可以轻松地根据市价比筛选公司，这意味着这种方法的潜在回报可能会很快被套利掉。换句话说，那些看上去很便宜的公司之所以便宜是有原因的。

;

;不过，这一切都无法阻止任何人担心引领今天牛市的股票估值已经过高，无法提供出色的未来回报。一个广受关注的指标是耶鲁大学罗伯特·希勒 (Robert Shiller) 设计的周期性调整市盈率 (;CAPE;)，该比率用价格除以过去十年经通胀调整后的收益。对于美国;S;和;P; 500指数来说，;CAPE;仅比现在高出两次：在互联网泡沫的顶峰时期，就在 2022 年崩盘之前。即使崩盘没有随之而来，高的 CAPE 比率从历史上来看也被证明是一个强有力的指标，表明未来的长期实际回报率会很差甚至为负。你几乎不需要成为一名真正的价值投资者，就能以此为线索去寻找其他地方。

;

;对于 Elm Partners 的 Victor Haghani 来说，对于一家基金管理公司来说，答案是显而易见的：放眼美国以外的地区。在更广阔的世界中，估值较低（见图 2）。哈加尼先生计算得出，尽管美国股票的总市盈率远高于其他国家的股票，但其基本收益的约 40% 来自海外。在世界其他地区，大约 20% 的总收入来自美国。换句话说，两组公司的实际利润存在很强的交叉性。

;
;;
;

;尽管如此，市场对来自美国和其他地方的收入的估值却截然不同。哈加尼先生的数字运算表明，为了从盈利中获得股价（美国和非美国股票），投资者将来自美国的股票规模扩大了 40 倍以上。对于来自其他国家的盈利世界上等效的缩放因子仅为 10。

;

;这种差异似乎没有什么意义。认为美国公司应该获得更高的估值是一回事，因为它们的增长潜力具有非凡的潜力。但为什么来自美国的收益比其他地方的收益对股价的推升幅度要大得多？

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;也许是美国以外国家的股票市场（或者同等地，即将到来的收益）来自这些国家）的价格相对而言被低估了。这只是一种错误定价，市场最终可能会通过提高非美国公司的估值、降低美国公司的估值或两者兼而有之来纠正。更重要的是，虽然价值投资通常涉及对个别公司或行业进行集中押注，但押注这种重新定价可以将风险分散到世界大部分地区。

;

;事实上，即使是美国以外的公司因为缺乏活力而应获得目前的低估值的论点也是陈词滥调。它经常以每个市场的部门构成来表述：美国充满了未来的颠覆性科技公司，而欧洲则充满了古板的银行和工业机构。

;

;但是，摩根大通资产管理公司的休·金伯(Hugh Gimber)对这种解释欧洲企业估值较低的观点泼了一盆冷水。他的团队按行业对非洲大陆的公司进行了划分，分析了它们的盈利放大的历史倍数以得出股价，然后将其与美国公司的同等倍数进行比较。在大多数行业中，欧洲公司的股票都遭受了长期平均折让。然而如今，这些折扣出现在每个行业，而且比长期平均水平要低得多（见图 3）。这些公司并非无法在尖端行业开展业务，而是可能只是定价过低。

;
;;< /div>;

;此类潜在价值交易不仅在欧洲比比皆是。金伯先生指出，一系列新兴市场国家都处于有利地位，可以从全球趋势中获利，而且这些国家的估值远不及美国那样令人瞠目结舌。例子包括从墨西哥和越南（受益于西方供应链的“友好外包”）到其他乘着<小>;人工智能;浪潮的国家，例如韩国和台湾。

;

;资产管理公司曼氏集团 (Man Group) 的延斯·福伦巴赫 (Jens Foehrenbach) 指出，东京证券交易所已为企业制定了明确的目标，要求他们采取行动，提高其股票的市净率（公司的市值除以净资产）高于 1。日本 Topix 指数中约有 42% 的成分股尚未达到这一水平，这对于那些认为最终会达到这一水平的人来说显然是一个明显的赌注。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;所有此类市场的一个共同特征是，就像任何价值投资一样，押注它们需要信仰的飞跃。美国股市跑赢其他市场的时间越长，这似乎就越是自然的事情。也许在其他地方上市的公司看起来更便宜，因为它们只是更糟糕。但有迹象表明，价格差异已经变得太大，专业投资者无法继续容忍。 3月份，全球基金经理告诉美国银行的调查，与上月相比，他们将更多的股票配置转向欧洲和新兴市场股票，这比多年来的做法要多。任何定价过低的产品都可能不会长期存在。 ;■;

;;;;威权主义的黑暗阴影;在印度筹备第 18 届大选之际笼罩在印度上空。纳伦德拉·莫迪 (Narendra Modi) 领导的现任印度人民党 (<小>;BJP;) 政府即将赢得第三个任期，调查显示，总理的个人支持率创历史新高。但他的治理建立在激进的集权基础上，以个人崇拜为合法性，并以排他性的印度教民族主义意识形态为基础，正在侵蚀印度的民主。如果不加以控制，该国的政治、经济和社会结构将受到严峻的后果。

;

;最明显的证据是以下事实：政治反对派、媒体、学术界和民间社会自由表达意见的空间正在迅速缩小。真正的民主需要对思想和政策进行积极的、公开的争论。取而代之的是，政府正在系统性地将调查机构、税法、煽动法、反恐法和监管外国资助<小>;非政府组织;的法律武器化，以不成比例地针对反对派政客，并将异见定为刑事犯罪。最厚颜无耻的例子是 ;3 月 21 日，德里首席部长、受欢迎的反对派人物 Arvind Kejriwal 被捕，当时竞选活动正在升温。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;新，阴险的政治集权形式正在合法化。两个州政府被剥夺了作为自治民选政府运作的权力，并置于中央控制之下——首先是查谟和巴布亚新几内亚。克什米尔在其特殊地位被取消后转变为联邦直辖区，后来又转变为德里。再加上日益支持莫迪个人崇拜的行政文化，危及了长期以来确立的联邦合作原则以及中央和各邦的双重责任原则。与此同时，议会几乎没有履行其审议职能，司法部门在保护公民自由方面也越来越谨慎。

;

;印度民主中的权力越来越大集权和独裁现在已得到充分记录。但其影响需要更多的反思。

;

;在政治领域，新的联邦断层线正在出现。印度根本不可能由一个回避联邦共识的狭隘而强大的中心来稳定和一致地治理。鉴于印度语言、地区和宗教的多样性，基于特定语言或种族的国家地位主张需要适应。印度的联邦制度提供了这一点，允许在民族国家框架内表达多重身份。

;

;印度教民族主义对这一原则不耐烦的适应，而是在“一个国家”内寻求单一的国家认同，由“双引擎”效率（借用;BJP;的口号）管理，由;BJP;政府推动中央和国家层面。这种意识形态框架削弱了调解民族和地区身份主张所需的政治信誉。例如，在东北部的曼尼普尔邦，其局限性已经很明显，该邦近一年来一直受到种族暴力的困扰。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;在经济领域，印度相对较繁荣的南部和西部地区与较贫穷但人口较多的北部各邦之间的发展差距日益扩大，给长期接受的分税和代表权原则带来了压力。此外，经济增长和全国市场的出现给国家间协调带来了新的压力。印度需要新的联邦契约和更强大的联邦机构。相反，;印度人民党;的集权倾向正在造成更加两极分化的联邦政治，这使得共识和合作变得困难。

;

;与此同时，技术使一种新型福利政治合法化：这种政治消除了地方领导人和州政府的传统中介，取而代之的是与围绕莫迪先生崇拜建立的接受者建立直接的情感联系唯一的恩人。福利计划被贴上个人“保障”的标签，上面贴满了总理的照片。政治学家 Neelanjan Sircar 将其描述为 ;vishwas;（信任）政治——一种以神化领导人以换取选民信任为前提的政治。 ;Vishwas;政治鼓励人们优先考虑福利作为直接福利，领导人可以在从烹饪煤气到厕所等领域直接获得这些福利。

;

;其中嵌入的是一种微妙的社会契约，它将福利定位为领导人的慷慨，而不是国家对享有权利的公民的道德义务。公民通过地方国家行为者（无论是政治家还是官僚）寻求问责制并要求福利服务。如今，这一点正在被牺牲在集权的;vishwas;政治的祭坛上。

;

;在社会领域，仇恨和仇恨针对印度 2 亿穆斯林的偏执正在因侵略性且经常暴力而加剧 ;印度教民族主义;。公共言论已经粗俗到如果你批评政府或其政策，你就是“反国家”的。如果你为世俗主义说话，你就是“反印度教徒”，一个“病态的自由主义者”。国家不但没有维护世俗主义和平等公民权的宪法理想，反而串通一气妖魔化穆斯林，推倒他们的家园，推行反穆斯林法律，同时有意识地将印度教特征融入治国之道。

;

;印度世俗主义是关于国家与宗教之间原则上的距离。它在反殖民自由运动中得到体现，作为宗教政治化的解毒剂，宗教政治化推动了竞争性的国家建设，最终导致分裂和暴力。世俗主义是多宗教社会通向和平与宽容的道路。在独立的印度，宪法对世俗主义、自由和平等的承诺是印度全球影响力的根本源泉。现在这种情况正处于危险之中。印度的精英甚至反对党在捍卫世俗主义方面越来越沉默。

;

;在印度的辩论中，过去领导人的独裁倾向——包括1970 年代英迪拉·甘地宣布进入紧急状态后的独裁时期——被用来淡化今天对民主侵蚀的恐惧。有人认为，它们只是痉挛，而不是政治体永久变化的最初迹象。事实是，20 世纪 70 年代，印度通过应对紧急状态来维护和深化民主。今天的集权和镇压方法不仅更加复杂和系统化，而且得到了更广泛的政治和机构认可。

;

;加上有毒的多数主义，印度的民主现在离它的宪政理想还有很长的路要走。因此，印度政治、经济和社会生活中的断层线正在扩大。维护民主是所有印度人必须进行的斗争。他们未来的繁荣取决于此。;■;

;Pants are also—though this is rarely noticed, since historians tend to prefer grander topics than gussets—important to British history.伯恩茅斯艺术大学时尚史教授雷切尔·沃斯 (Rachel Worth) 表示，对于衣服来说，它们的穿着效果和清洗方便程度“对女性来说至关重要”。 ;M;&;S; helped to improve both.

;

;And more besides.该连锁店于 1884 年在利兹成立，主要兜售干货，并于 1926 年开始销售服装，到 20 世纪 90 年代已成为欧洲最赚钱的商店。它仍然是英国商业街的主打产品，受到年轻人和老年人的拥护。它改变了这个国家的饮食、穿着和生活方式。 it is a thread running through 20th-century British history.

;
;

;;M;&;S; was the first British shop to use sell-by dates;第一家销售新鲜而非冷冻鸡肉的大型零售商（其他商店担心食物中毒）；第一个销售可机洗羊毛的公司（它帮助开发了这一产品）。 It was a pioneer in measuring women's bodies to ensure clothing sizes measured up (an earlier sizing method had rested on measurements taken from 1m conscripts in the American civil war which, though useful for men, was less helpful for a housewife in Hemel Hempstead).

;

;;M;&;S; also specialised in selling synthetic fabrics: nylon and Rayon and Terylene and Crimplene.这种面料对于现代人来说听起来很滑稽，但正如该公司前任负责人西蒙·马克斯(Simon Marks)所说，它们对于“减轻家庭主妇的日常负担”具有非常重要的意义。关于洗衣机等节省劳力的设备的文章有很多。人们经常忘记的是，其中需要坚固的（通常是合成的）材料。 Such fabrics “freed women up” says Professor Worth.; ;Long before women were liberated by burning their bras, they were liberated by being able to pop them in the twin tub and let them drip dry.

;

;To step into the archives at Leeds is an odd experience. At first sight, it feels like any other archive. But open its boxes and another world appears. In one box is a beautiful 1940s pink silken bra, the cups puffed up with tissue paper as if by a ghostly bosom. On a nearby rail hang dressing gowns: one post-war and woolly, one diaphanous, one of a paisley-ish pattern a 1950s father might have worn. Each is almost unbearably evocative of its era. Proust might have had his madeleines. Britons have ;M;&;S; Crimplene cardigans. ;■;

;

;;Enough: Why It's Time to Abolish the Super Rich. ;By Luke Hildyard.

;;

;;T;;wo new; books argue for doing away with the rich.这并不是波尔布特意义上的谋杀所有人，因为作者——荷兰伦理学教授和英国左翼智囊团的主任——都非常友善。 Rather, they favour policies that would make it impossible to have “too much” money.

;

;How much is too much? 《限制主义》一书的作者、荷兰乌得勒支大学的英格丽·罗宾斯认为，国家应该阻止任何人积累超过1000万美元（或英镑、或欧元；这是一个粗略的数字）。除了这种严格的“政治限制”之外，她认为还应该有一个低得多的“道德限制”。 In countries where the state pays for health care and pensions, no one should amass more than $1m in savings, and society should scorn anyone who does.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Luke Hildyard, who runs the High Pay Centre in London and whose book is called “Enough”, stops short of an “absolute cap” but suggests something close to it.他认为，任何人的收入都不应该超过目前进入前 1% 纳税人的门槛。 (In Britain that was over £180,000 a year in 2021-2; in America it was about $330,000 in 2021). Redistributing additional income or wealth beyond this point, or enacting policies so that such riches never accrue in the first place, “has no real downsides”, he claims.

;

;The authors offer many reasons for loathing the loaded.他们拥有私人飞机并偶尔在太空度假，这对环境有害。他们拥有多套住房，加剧了住房短缺。其中一些人购买政治影响力。有些人通过腐败手段获得了财富。实用主义者可能会通过对碳排放征税、允许建造更多房屋、收紧竞选财务法或打击腐败来直接解决这些问题。 But for Ms Robeyns and Mr Hildyard, everything depends on cutting the rich down to size.

;

;They make the reasonable point that the marginal benefit of an extra $1,000 is greater for the poor than the rich.一个饥饿的家庭可以买几个月的食物；银行家可能会在一顿晚餐上大赚一笔，不包括酒。不过，作者更进一步将一系列弊病归咎于不平等的加剧。他们认为，一个更加平等的社会压力会更小（不会有激烈的竞争！），而且会更有凝聚力（更少的嫉妒！）。 The money hoarded by the rich could be used to uplift the poor and improve public services.

;

;Mr Hildyard makes these points more concisely—and with flashes of wit.他反复提到需要多少张纸币才能覆盖英国的每一层楼——五英镑相当于 1.7 万亿英镑（2.1 万亿美元）——让这位评论家笑了，他对毫无意义的奢侈品的相对价格的思考也让他笑了。 A one-hour guest appearance at your birthday party from James Corden, a British comedian who likes to sing karaoke in cars, is about as costly as a half-kilo of cocaine, apparently.

;
;
;When it comes to practicalities, however, both books lose their grip.究竟如何才能消灭富人呢？希尔亚德先生支持最高工资和高额财富税等措施。 Robeyns 教授表示，这需要一系列政策的拼凑，而那些试图通过将其描述为 100% 的边际税率来过分简化她的想法的人感到恼火。 But if she is serious when she says that $10m should be “as hard a limit as possible”, that implies something very close to a marginal tax rate of 100%.

;

;
;Such a policy would provoke tax-avoidance on an epic scale.聪明的顾问会竭尽全力帮助富人隐藏他们的财富或将其转移到更友好的司法管辖区。如果政府能够克服困难，阻止这些骗局，那么许多富人就会移民。 And if governments all adopted similar wealth-banning policies and enforcement was tight, as the authors desire, the effects would be even worse.

;

;Imagine a world where any gain above £180,000 a year, or $10m over a lifetime, was forfeit.高生产力的人——比如外科医生和工程师，更不用说像 JK 罗琳这样的文字奇才——在这一点过去后将没有经济动力继续工作。也许有些人会出于利他主义或出于对工作的热爱而继续努力工作。 But many would be tempted to kick back, relax and deprive the world of their exceptional skills, drive and imagination.

;

;
;Consider, too, the incentives such a system would create for entrepreneurs.你有一个更好的捕鼠器的想法。在旧制度下，你可能会抵押你的房子来筹集资金建造一个捕鼠器工厂，以期发财。 Under the new system, you must shoulder the same risks (such as losing your home), for a small fraction of the rewards.

;

;Potentially big ideas would stay small.即使你的捕鼠器非常好，可以合理地预期全世界都会向你敞开大门，借钱来扩大生产也是不合理的。尝试建立全球业务的财务风险落在您身上。奖励归别人所有。 Only a mug would take such a bet.

;

;Or a politician, betting with other people's money.事实上，大多数需要大量前期资本的企业——从芯片工厂到海上风电场——可能必须由国家拥有或支持。 Since the record of state-run industries over the past century has been one of cronyism, sluggishness and inefficiency, this ought to have given the authors pause.

;

;Like many on the left, they gloss over the huge fall in global poverty over the past few decades and focus on inequality within countries, which they are sure is rising inexorably thanks to the unfairness of capitalism. But is it?今年 3 月，纽约联邦储备银行经济学家马克西姆·平科夫斯基 (Maxim Pinkovskiy) 和他的合著者发表了新的估计，表明 1980 年至 2019 年间，全球不平等现象急剧下降，而自 90 年代以来，各国内部的不平等现象几乎没有变化。 (Though an asset-price boom later increased wealth inequality.) 

;

;;T;;HE CO-FOUNDER; of the Miami marathon, Frankie Ruiz, was once asked on the radio if he was related to the most famous marathon cheat of all time.罗西·鲁伊斯 (Rosie Ruiz) 只跑了 1980 年波士顿马拉松比赛预期 26 英里（42 公里）的成绩之一。不过，尽管她可能与鲁伊斯先生有相同的名字和古巴血统，但相似之处仅此而已。 Mr Ruiz is even mulling an expensive investment—;AI;-powered facial-recognition cameras—to ensure that no runner, be they first or last, ever pulls a Rosie during one of his events.

;

;Cheating in distance running has a long and varied history. 1904 年圣路易斯奥运会上，20 岁的瓦工弗雷德里克·洛兹 (Frederick Lorz) 在跑完大约 10 英里的马拉松后跳进了一辆汽车。十英里后，他找到了恢复的力量，并毫无意外地获得了第一名。 He allowed a wreath to be laid upon his head before his unsanctioned assistance was revealed.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Lorz seems to have been an opportunist. （圣路易斯的比赛是由一个不相信补水的疯子组织的，据说是地狱般的。）其他人做了更多的准备。 1999 年，在一场 54 英里超级马拉松比赛中，南非跑步运动员塞尔吉奥·莫特索宁 (Sergio Motsoeneng) 与他的兄弟分担跑步任务，并在厕所里交换了衣服。 Motsoeneng 先生以第十名的成绩（距离不到 54 英里）获得的奖金对于他的九个兄弟姐妹来说是很大的。 2010 年，基普·利顿 (Kip Litton) 甚至在怀俄明州策划了自己的马拉松比赛，以不同的名字冒充赛事总监，并宣布自己获胜。 Mr Litton has said that the event was a legitimate attempt at a marathon, but he agreed that a friend could falsify names of other participants when no one else showed up on the day.

;

;Marathon cheats pose a special sort of problem.精英运动员与周末战士共享道路。第一组受到严格监管：如果您要登上领奖台，您将接受药物测试并进行直播。人们确实会碰碰运气。 (The Athletics Integrity Unit, an anti-doping watchdog, maintains a list of banned athletes.) But blatant course-cutting is not a realistic proposition for the speedsters.

;

;Runners back in the pack are less likely to be spotted.作弊行为并不十分猖獗——2023 年墨西哥城马拉松的奇怪案例是一个例外，其中大约三分之一的参与者被取消资格。 But though it seems akin to cheating at the crossword, amateur cheating happens;.; And when ordinary people face such allegations, it is generally ordinary people who make them.

;

;Derek Murphy, a data analyst from Ohio, has published claims about scores of amateur runners on his website, Marathon Investigation.他扫描比赛结果，计算错过的分段时间（通常在跑步者经过垫子时自动记录的临时时间），看看它们是否叠加。如果只有四分钟的里程夹在八分钟的里程之间，赛车手的完赛时间才有意义，那么他可能在某个地方使用了自行车。 Mr Murphy also buys race photos, zooming in on athletes' ;GPS; watches, which show various details relating to their run. He once got a runner disqualified by showing that according to her watch she had run just 11.6 miles of a 13.1-mile race.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;His project is divisive. 2019年，他一名70岁的跑步者被指控串行作弊自杀。墨菲先生恰当地发现自己在互联网暴民的另一侧，他通常被指控鼓舞人心。他说，他现在专注于根据其结果召集正在建立个人或商业品牌的人。 “跑步者”的崛起使指控似乎更为有道理。奖金可能不会受到威胁，而是赞助和自我。历史学家和超级马拉松运动员拉夫堡大学的山姆·爱德华兹（Sam Edwards）将这个时代描述为“竞争性生活方式”之一。 He compares cheating in races to “photo-shopping an insta image before posting”: both tweak reality in pursuit of realistic-enough perfection.

;

;Flora Beverley, a British runfluencer, concedes that social media creates pressures to perform. Her kosher but disappointing time of four and a half hours in her first marathon earned her “so much hate”. But she insists that the risks of cheating are worse. Social media magnifies the incentives to fudge times, but also makes it harder to get away with. ;

;Of course, these self-appointed investigators are not always right.说出可疑的业余作弊者的名字会像电子游戏一样令人兴奋。但其影响却在现实世界中产生了反响。发给赛事总监的私人电子邮件比投机性的公开帖子是一个更明智的起点。不过，当跑步界的侦探变得探究或令人讨厌时，有影响力的人可能会忘记他们已经引起了人们的关注，这也是事实。他们比许多人更能理解对更大舞台的渴望。 ;■;

;;H;;ardly a month ;goes by without ;antitrust regulators; taking another swipe at big-tech firms. 3 月 21 日，轮到苹果了。 America's Department of Justice (;D;o;J;) along with attorneys-general from 16 states sued the company.该案指控该公司利用其在智能手机市场的垄断地位“阻碍”创新、“遏制”竞争对手并阻止用户购买竞争对手的设备。苹果表示，该诉讼是错误的，它将“大力捍卫”自己。 Nonetheless the case marks an escalation in a regulatory onslaught against the once-charmed iPhone-maker.

;

;The suit is broader than those trustbusters have previously brought against Apple.这些攻击往往集中在该公司的 App Store 上，这是该公司设备上唯一允许使用的应用商店，并且该公司对大多数应用内购买收取 30% 的费用。然而，最新的案例对苹果公司运营整个业务的方式提出了质疑。它引用了该公司据称压制竞争对手的几个例子，以此来巩固自己的主导地位。其中包括：阻止超级应用程序，这些应用程序汇集了多种微型服务，例如支付和消息传递；阻止访问基于云的游戏应用程序（这可能会鼓励用户购买更便宜、不太时髦的智能手机，因为游戏在云中运行良好）；当智能手表等竞争对手的产品与 iPhone 交互时，会导致服务质量不佳。 Apple's share price fell by about 4% on the news.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The case adds to Apple's other legal headaches. The ;EU;'s Digital Markets Act, which came into effect on March 6th, forced the company to make changes to the App Store.其中包括允许 iPhone 应用程序开发商在不使用苹果设备的情况下向用户收费并分发他们的应用程序，从而绕过 30% 的佣金。苹果的新系统仍然向应用程序开发商收取高额费用。 Regulators in Brussels are reportedly preparing to investigate.

;

;Apple may also be forced to open up the App Store to outside payments in America as a result of a recent ruling to a suit brought by Epic, a video-game maker.苹果已经提出了一项遵守计划。但 Epic 以及 Meta 和微软等大型科技公司已向联邦法官提出申诉，称其仍会使替代支付变得异常困难。 In a separate case, the ;D;o;J; has sued Google for deals it has struck with Apple and other firms to make it the default search engine on their devices. A loss could deprive Apple of $20bn each year in almost pure profit. Google denies wrongdoing.

;

;Apple will take solace from the fact that the government has flubbed some of its recent attempts to defeat big tech in court.另一个监管机构美国联邦贸易委员会试图对微软收购视频游戏制造商动视暴雪提出质疑，但失败了。 It could not halt Meta's purchase of Within, a virtual-reality (;VR;) fitness company. As Matt Perault, director of the University of North Carolina's Center on Technology Policy, says, “It may be easy to write antitrust op-eds and hold hearings, but actually winning cases is hard.”

;The battle with Apple may drag on for years.但即使公司获胜，它仍然可能承受后果。旷日持久的法律混乱可能会分散高层管理人员的注意力。它可能会损害公司的品牌。 Already the company has its work cut out trying to reinvigorate iPhone sales.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;If it loses, Apple could probably shrug off a fine.人们更担心法院会试图打破其独特的生态系统，在该生态系统中，20亿台设备及其提供的服务增强了彼此的需求。苹果为这个所谓的围墙花园辩护，称这对于保护用户的安全和隐私至关重要。 Whether that is true or not, the firm's business could suffer if it is forced to make its iPhones more interoperable with rivals' devices, such as smartwatches and ;VR; headsets, rather than its own.

;

;As it is, technology never stands still. If big tech is dominant now, it may become even more so thanks to “generative” artificial intelligence (;AI;), which favours firms that have access to oceans of data, cash and ;IT; talent. The “Magnificent Seven” (Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta, Microsoft, Nvidia and Tesla) account for 29% of the market value of the ;S&P ;500, up from 20% at the start of 2023. This is largely thanks to the ;AI; boom.

;

;Notwithstanding the trustbusters' scrutiny, the giants are manoeuvring to stay ahead. This week it emerged that Apple is in talks with Google, owned by Alphabet, to let the search giant's Gemini gen-;AI; model power some iPhone features, building on both companies' search deal.美国反垄断监管机构关注的是过去被认为的罪恶。这听起来越来越像昨天的战争。 ;■;

;;I;;T IS DIFFICULT; for a democracy to spread its values abroad when it is undermining them at home. Joe Biden, America's president, knows that all too well. In his presidential campaign in 2020 he promised to rejuvenate democracy around the world. In office he has spent nearly four years refuting false claims that he stole the election from Donald Trump. (More than half of Republicans still think that Mr Biden did not win in 2020.) Democracy around the world is ;not in great shape; either.

;;
;;;
;

;Surveys show that Americans' trust in their system of government is hitting new lows. A democracy index created by ;EIU;, our sister company, demoted America from a “full democracy” to a “flawed” one in 2016. It has kept that status ever since (see chart 1). America was once seen around the world as a standard-bearer for democracy. What went wrong?

;

;;EIU; data suggest what aspects of democracy are weakest. The overall scores are based on five categories, each marked on a scale of one to ten (see chart 2). Even with Mr Trump's baseless claims of voter fraud in the 2016 and 2020 elections, America still scores highly in its ability to hold legitimate elections. (Despite the pro-Trump insurrection before Mr Biden's inauguration, America got the president that it voted for.) On political participation (ie, voter turnout) and electoral process and pluralism (ie, free and fair elections) America scores around nine points out of ten.

;;;

;Instead, it is America's political culture and the functioning of its government that pose the biggest problems. Within the culture category, America scores poorly on political polarisation and general support for democracy. A recent survey by Pew, a pollster, found that more than a quarter of Americans think that an autocracy—in which a leader can bypass Congress and the courts—would be a somewhat or very good form of government.
; 
;On government functionality, America's score is weighed down by mistrust of elected officials and perceptions of corruption. The same survey by Pew found that more than 80% of respondents believed that most political figures “don't care” about “what people like me think”. In Sweden, a full democracy, just 43% of people think that. Gridlock in Congress over big issues, such as ;control of the border; and ;aid for Ukraine;, probably undermines Americans' sense of trust.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Polarisation and mistrust are connected: America's increasingly divided electorate votes for increasingly extreme candidates. That encourages the perception among a majority of voters, at any given time, that the government is led by people who are not acting in their best interests. Just 40% of moderates say that there is a party in America that represents their opinions.

;

;America's downgrade to flawed-democracy status coincided with the election of Mr Trump. But the trend was in motion years before he assumed office. One survey from 2012 found that 80% of Democrats approved of Barack Obama compared with just 12% of Republicans—at that time the largest partisan gap for any president's third year of office. The flaws are unlikely to fade if Mr Trump wins a second term. But, as ;EIU;'s index demonstrates, American democracy will remain troubled regardless of who wins in November.;■;

;;G;;REG ABBOTT;, the governor of Texas, watched his dream of a state-run immigration policy become reality this week. On March 19th America's Supreme Court ruled that Texas could—at least temporarily—enforce ;Senate Bill 4; (;SB;4), a law that makes it a state crime for migrants to cross Texas's border with Mexico between legal ports of entry (see map). The bill gives local police the authority to arrest people they suspect of coming to America illegally and empowers state judges to order deportations. This was the first time that a state had assumed these powers, which had been reserved for the federal government.

;

;But Mr Abbott's triumph lasted less than nine hours. The Supreme Court's emergency ruling was a stopgap that lobbed the question of ;SB;4's legality down to the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals, the region's federal appellate court. That night three judges in New Orleans decided to put the law on hold while they deliberate on its merits in the coming weeks. Immigration advocates who worried that ;SB;4 would put a target on Latinos' backs were relieved; Mr Abbott said he felt as if he was watching a tennis rally.

;;
;;
;

;Mr Abbott thinks Joe Biden's policy on immigration is too lax. Acting on that belief, he has picked a legal fight over which level of government has the right to control border policy. In January the Biden administration sued Texas over ;SB;4, arguing that it violates the supremacy clause of the constitution, which makes the federal government the chief arbiter of immigration policy. Texas reckons that it is being “invaded” by migrants.在此基础上，它声称自己有权根据美国宪法的州战争条款进行自卫——该条款禁止各州在未经国会同意的情况下发动战争，除非它们“实际上被入侵”或处于“迫在眉睫的危险”。 Ken Paxton, Texas's attorney-general, has said that he hopes to provoke the Supreme Court into revisiting its decision in 2012 in the case of ;Arizona v United States;, which set the precedent that states cannot enforce their own immigration regimes. Legal experts expect the question of ;SB;4's constitutionality to bounce back to the nine justices in the coming months.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;To persuade the court Texas's lawyers will have to prove two things. First, that the migrants pose enough of a threat to justify declaring war against them. And, second, that Texas can override federal law in order to defend itself. That will be hard.加利福尼亚州、纽约州和宾夕法尼亚州的上诉法院将宪法中提到的入侵解释为政敌或外国武装部队的武装敌对。 It is difficult to imagine how asylum-seekers fit that description. The Supreme Court has also held that if the federal government responds to such an invasion, states must “give way” to federal policy. That would suggest that, although Texas loathes the Biden administration's border policy, the very  existence of that policy is an argument against the constitutionality of the state's plan.

;;W;;HILE APPLYING ;to ;Yale University; (pictured) in 2014, Rob Henderson visited New Haven for the first time. He stayed with a friend of a friend, whose cat was called Learned Claw (an obscure, pretentious allusion to an American judge of the mid-20th century who went by the name of Learned Hand). Mr Henderson did not get the reference. When he arrived at Yale more cultural mysteries awaited. Everyone raved about “The West Wing”, a television show he had never watched, and “;Hamilton;”, a musical he could not afford to see.

;

;More Yale students come from families in the top 1% of income than from the bottom 60%. Mr Henderson was among the ;less-affluent minority.; He had been removed from his drug-addicted mother when he was three years old and lived with nine different foster families before his eighth birthday. Scared, insecure and angry, he soon began to drink, take drugs and get into fights.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;At the age of 17, as his peers started going to prison, he signed up to the armed forces on a whim. Mr Henderson thrived in the structured, disciplined system and spent seven years in the ;US ;Air Force. It became clear he was highly intelligent, so he was encouraged to apply to college through the ;GI; Bill. (He has recently finished a doctorate at Cambridge University.)

;

;“Troubled” is the compelling story of his chaotic childhood, his time at Yale and what it all made him think about divisions in America. As a result of his experience, Mr Henderson has coined the concept of “luxury beliefs”, which he describes as “a set of beliefs that confer status on the upper class at very little cost, while inflicting costs upon the lower classes”.

;

;In the past, people displayed their membership of the upper class either by doing things “like golf or beagling” that no working person would have time to do, or through their material accoutrements. But today, leisure time and luxury goods are more accessible to everyone, so it has become harder for the elites to separate themselves from the hoi polloi.他们的解决方案？ “The affluent have decoupled social status from goods and reattached it to beliefs.”

;

;Mr Henderson gives the example of support for defunding the police. The idea gained traction in the wake of ;George Floyd's murder; in 2020 and has been championed by many affluent people. However, it is an unpopular policy among poor people—exactly those who the well-meaning college kids say they are trying to help—and leads to ;higher homicide rates;.

;

;“Troubled” is more than a fascinating memoir, as it analyses the controversial belief systems that have gripped American universities. But it does so without being an angry culture-war screed. Mr Henderson makes no statement of political affiliation. Lots of what he writes is simply common sense. It is what much of middle America believes.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Mr Henderson exposes the stupidity of what now passes for orthodoxy, such as the way the luxury-belief class claims that the unhappiness associated with substance abuse or ;obesity;, for instance, “primarily stems from the negative social judgments they elicit, rather than the behaviours and choices themselves”. The well-off “validate and affirm the behaviours, decisions, and attitudes of marginalised and deprived kids” in a way “that they would never accept for themselves or their own children”. One classmate argues that ;monogamy; is “outdated” but admits that she was raised by two parents and intends to have a monogamous marriage herself.

;

;Youngsters today are fond of talking about “lived experience”: the idea that an individual enjoys authority on particular subjects owing to their identity, history and perspective. Mr Henderson's background gives him the legitimacy to raise his concerns, but that does not mean his peers are paying attention. When he tries to speak with his Yale classmates, no one wants to listen. Readers, however, will be rapt. ;■;
